segments.text: Testing, one, two, three.
This is an interview with Dr. A.K.
Ayub, currently a professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering at Texas A&M.
Dr. Ayub, could you tell us a little bit about your early years?
I was born in Egypt in 1927.
I attended my primary school, got my school education after B.Sc.
in electrical engineering in Egypt, and then I came to the United States in 1949 on a scholarship to work for a Ph.D., a scholarship from the Egyptian government.
I got my degree in 1955, and I did do some work for
General Electric in 55 and 56.
Then I went to Egypt in 56.
Is this early enough?
Yeah, that's fine.
Okay, what were your parents' occupations?
My father is a retired man now.
He's in his 80s and used to be a judge.
A judge?
Okay.
How did your interest in electrical engineering develop?
It developed in the late 30s and early 40s.
There was talk in Egypt about constructing high dams and electric generation from hydro plants and the like.
And I thought that was very fascinating, so I did do it there.
When did you get your Ph.D.?
When?
Yeah.
In 1955, January 1955, University of Texas in Austin.
Okay.
What did you do your doctoral dissertation on?
My dissertation was on federal residents on power systems.
Okay.
From 1955 until 1961, you worked for the Ministry of Public Works in Cairo, Egypt, in the Mechanical and Engineering Department.
What positions did you hold there?
I was a project engineer when I got there after my scholarship, and then I climbed the ladder and I became what is translated as General Inspector.
I was a chief engineer for a while, and then I was a general manager for a while, until 1961, in power generation and distribution.
Could you compare engineering in Egypt and the United States?
Oh, yeah.
Comparing engineering as such is not a very precise thing.
You see, Egypt had very strong ties with the United Kingdom for the last 100 years.
And most of the electrical installations, electrical practices and codes are more or less the British standard.
So, you can say that
We're closer to the European practices than we are to the States.
As you know, the States is the only place in the world with 60 cycle businesses.
Other than that, same kind of practices.
When you left the Ministry of Public Works in 1961, you went to work for the Atomic Energy Establishment also in Cairo.
Why did you make this move?
Well, see, in the late 50s,
The research and the lust, the glamour, the whole field is changing.
Power systems were very stagnant in the way of research.
And electronics was coming up in one area, you know, this kind of thing.
I felt at the time that, I was 35 at the time, I left about 35 years of age,
And I felt like it was time to change a little bit.
So I did contact and almost came to North Carolina State for a Ph.D. in nuclear physics on my own, just coming back from a study leave and getting a Ph.D. in physics.
And it just so happened before I left for this newer education,
Some people approached me from the Atomic Energy establishment in Egypt and asked me if I would participate with them in the development of a nuclear power program for Egypt.
And when I mentioned that I was on my way to the States to get more education in nuclear physics, just to happen that way, they offered an alternative.
They offered me the alternative of going to the Soviet Union.
They sent me to the Soviet Union.
to get my nuclear engineering education there, and that they'd send me to England.
And they did.
So I went to the reactor schools, and one was in Moscow called the Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy.
And then later on, I went to the Harvard Reactor School in England, Atomic Energy Establishment of Harvard.
At the time, there were no nuclear engineering departments in universities or such.
The only nuclear education you'd get would be if you were a mechanical or electrical engineer or a physicist maybe.
You can come to the States and go to one of the five national labs, Argonne National Lab and Oak Ridge.
or go to England to Harvard, as they did, and go to the Soviet Union to .
So there were no departments at the time.
There were no degrees in nuclear engineering.
So that's how I got involved in that.
I came back from all these educational missions, and I did take part with them in the planning of the first nuclear power plants and nuclear desalination versions.
in Egypt.
At the time, if your people would remember, you would not.
Eisenhower had a plan called the Eisenhower Plan in which he suggested to build a large complex of nuclear power in the Sinai Desert and have a joint operation of it by Egypt and Israel.
It was one way of getting Egypt and Israel to have peace.

is for Eisenhower to offer that America would build a nuclear power plant that would use nuclear energy to produce electrical power and enough heat to desalt seawater and use it for irrigation for the Sinai Desert.
And politically, the Eisenhower plan would not fly, but there was this kind of
idea.
And in the meantime, the Egyptian government did proceed with its own plans of getting its own nuclear power plants and what have you.
And they went to the international market with Germany and the States and England and France.
And I took part in that, a good part of that, until 1968.
What major accomplishments have electrical engineers in the past 25 years come up with?
Major accomplishments?
The major accomplishments that the WES came up with have changed the face of the era, in my opinion.
produced a civilization that was never surpassed in the whole human history in the last few decades.
Solid state electronics and the new technologies we see and the control system that made you control all these missiles and all these spaceships and what have you.
marvelous job in changing the way that everybody lives.
Now you see the transistor radios in any, all the corners of the air, in deserts, right?
Totally isolated places, people are having radio recorders and radios.
So I think the computer era also has ushered in the last 20 years
and in no time at all is going to permeate everybody's life.
So I think their contribution is really fascinating in the last few years.
What new fields and discoveries have you seen open up in the past 25 years in electro-engineering?
Well, the Second World War, when I came to the States,
I went to the University of Texas in Austin.
Someone suggested in 1950 that I work on relays, solid-state relays, rather than electromagnetic relays for my dissertation.
And I said, what's that?
So they brought me some declassified information,
two, three volumes, vehicles from the Navy, it was about transistors.
They were not in books.
They were not taught.
They were just coming out in classified material.
I think that was ushering the whole thing, the whole era that we are in today.
It was the post-war period and the transistors and the like.
did not, for some reason or another, I was not really fascinated by the idea of going to electronics and all this at the time.
So I did not really pursue this any further.
And then at the time, we were also hearing about these first generation computers.
We were just talking about new names and what they do and this kind of thing.
So I think that part, the early 50s, very early 50s, 51, 52, 53,
Again, one of the declassified areas, I mean, the control system of business.
When I was going to school in the early 50s, there were two books in the control field, two.
One was by Chestnut and Meyer from GE, and the other was Brown and Camp.
Now there are hundreds of them, and the theory has
Again, most of that work probably was classified in the 45 and 44 era, you see, position control and gun positioning and the like, you see, this kind of thing was.
So I think that that period, the early 50s, that saw the transistors coming out and saw computers coming out, control theory pursued very actively in research, this kind of thing.
was a very, very important period for the change.
The other change that I had just missed would be in the early 30s, you see, where many of the accomplishments in my own area, in the power systems area, were made by people.
Somehow in the late 20s and early 30s, there was a lot of work done, and the result of it is what we have to really today, what we have added mostly is...
some kind of a sophisticated formulation of problems and solutions by computer business, computer methods, you see.
But most of the ideas, the concepts, the attacks, the approaches to things, you see, were in the persistent area, were formulated there with .
OK. How did the switchover, say, from vacuum tubes to solid-state electronics affect electrical engineering as a profession?

we just finished talking about that i think it's uh it just opened whole new horizons as you see and then when when jack kilby and his work and these integrated circuits and what have you then you have calculators in your hand i i bought a hp 45 six years ago for 400 bucks
Today I have a 41 CV for 200.
Have you seen any new discoveries?
Have there been any in, say, the past 20 years?
Discoveries in what?
In electrical engineering.
I don't know exactly what you mean by discoveries, but I'm, again, pointing at the solid-state electronics area.
And...
I guess they have these cars every day.
They just do things every day.
In 1967, Dr. Jones became the head of the electrical engineering department at A&M.
You came to A&M in 1968 at a time when the department really began to expand.
What were your reasons for coming here?
I came here by accident.
At the time, in 1968, I had an offer from the United Nations to work as an advisor, as the advisor to the government of Indonesia for system development, the United Nations at the time.
They still do.
They had a program called the Technical Assistance Program
And we had a roster of experts from all over the world in all areas.
And whenever a country needed technical assistance, then the United Nations would pick one of the experts on the roster and suggest him to the government, and he would serve with them.
So at the time, I did have an appointment from the United Nations for assistance with government.
And I was in this country at the time.
And I had talked to Mr. Dennison.
I didn't know Jones.
I knew some of the parties.
I finished in Austin, so I'm always familiar with the area here.
And at the time, my two sons, one was 10 and the other was 8.
And the idea of...
of settling down some at this age for them to go to school and get educated and raised about 100 miles from her grandparents and family.
My wife is a Texan, and her family, they all live in Correale County Corporate School in that area, which is 100 miles from here, 125 miles from here.
A decision that I just made at the time, you know, because it sounded to be maybe best for the family, this kind of thing.
Dr. Abe, you've participated in the Electric Power Research Institute program at A&M since you first arrived.
Could you tell us about that program?
Yeah, the Electric Power Institute, as you probably know, is an organization within the EE department.
which is supported by the Texas utilities.
It has been supported since 1966 by 12 Texas utilities until recently.
One of them dropped out, so we have 11 now.
And they pay money annually.
Each utility pays its share annually.
And the purpose is to
encourage research in the power systems area that will give results that will be useful to the utilities, number one.
Number two is that they would like to encourage students to enroll in the power systems courses and get into the power system area.
In other words, they'd like for us to prepare people that they can hire to fill their positions.
So they are interested in education, in power system education, and in power system research that has practical value, not academic or not just that for the purpose of publishing.
They just want something useful that they can use and people can use.
What are some of the companies that participate in this program?
Oh, they all do, from Houston Library of Power and Dallas
Texas Utilities, Central Power and Light, all the Texas Utilities, the 12 of them.
Started there.
What changes have you seen in that program since you've been here?
The EPI program?
Yeah.
Which program?
The Electric Power Institute program.
When we started, really, in 66, just before I came, it was...
Professor Dennison, he's retired now, he retired this year, John S. Dennison, was here, and I think he was the only one in there.
He started the program there.
And then apparently at the same time, or slightly after that, Mr. Patton was hired.
He didn't have a degree then.
He got his PhD here later on in 1974.
But he was hired.
He had his master's from Pittsburgh, and he was hired here.
And then I came in 68.
So there was a few of us where we were deemed as a group at the time.
Over the years, we stayed like this until, I'd say, 75, 74, yeah, something like that.
And then we started hiring more people.
So today, we have, I mean, we just
people.
We have Dr. Hassani and Dr. Singh and Dr. Russell and Dr. Wang has been hired recently.
He's a mathematician and mathematics and systems man, but he works in the nuclear systems area.
And Dr. Chenoweth and myself.
We have six feet.
So instead of two or three, now we're six.
The areas of interest also have changed now.

We do have, before we hired new people, we were interested mostly in power system reliability, which is the application of probability methods to calculate indices to tell me whether this design is reliable or not, will it perform the way I want it or not, this kind of thing.

uh russell and aksani and all of these we have new areas of interest one of them is i go to the dc power electronics in general it's a power conditioning you know power electronics which is a new area to us mr aksani works in there and then we have
Russell was interested in automation and distribution system automation and using the microcomputers and the like.
So we did expand in size and interest.
Can you give us some examples of what other researchers in the electrical engineering department have accomplished at A&M?
The department?
would not really be, I won't be able really to tell you much about the others.
We do have some, an institute, we have that solar state electronics institute upstairs, Dr. Parker handles that, and he should be able to tell you more about it.
In the control area,
You see me, I don't know, I mean, you see me hesitate a little bit here.
I don't know how much you're going to place on this interview, but you see, the thing that makes me hesitate is that we had such an experience, you know, recent in the last few years, you know.
Some people are not here all together.
We lost quite a few of our faculty, if you remember.
Last year we lost 30% of our faculty within a year.
So I would not be able to enumerate what these people have been doing or why they left or anything like that.
But we had some bad experiences, I would say.
And I hope you don't spread that around.
In the mid-60s, very little money was allotted to research in electrical engineering at A&M.
Today, about $1.4 million is allotted to research.
What effect has this increase in spending on projects had on the department?
You see, in the late 60s, the whole department was 25.
The personnel were 25 people, faculty and staff.
Two years ago, we reached our faculty, the research and teaching faculty was 65 people.
And the research was quite a bit of the time they spent.
Many of them were paid of that money you're talking about.
So we did grow, and the money that we had meant growth, like you see there.

and then uh we lost some of these we lost 20 or something but they we did grow that and we had more facilities built that uh so state electronics lab i'm telling you about their floors was started with doctors kip porter the man who is now heading the tees he came here at the same time i came
I think it has expanded quite a bit.
It does have a good status.
I talk to people about it.
In 1975, you went on leave for two years as professor and head of the new Department of Electrical Engineering at the University of Kuwait.
Can you tell us what differences in engineering you saw there as compared to here?
Well, the University of Kuwait
did not have a college of engineering altogether.
So in 1975, in August 1975, I walked in the University of Kuwait, and I was given the keys to a new building where engineering was supposed to be established.
So I was the first one who walked in the building.

in 1975 and at the time they started a mechanical electrical engineering department and mechanical union department civil engineering and chemical engineering only four departments and it so happened that one the man who was in charge of mechanical engineering who was head then walked in with me right after i did
was also a professor here.
And we were entrusted, of course, with the task of designing the curriculum, specifying and establishing the labs, the library, and staff.
It was a new college altogether.
You see, I got there on the 23rd of August, 1975.

the 15th of september we had students enrolled you see for the first year so the the curriculum design and lab facilities and this faculty that we hired were highly influenced by the by the system we have here of course as you suspect when i i i
They drove my observations here and my experience here.
In other words, you would say that their curriculum for electrical engineering is very similar to ours.
It would be.
I suspect that.
And then the faculty, the platform staff, I had to sit all of that.
I was supposed to be there for a year.
So after the one year was over, they did ask the university to leave me there another year.

So the plan for everything, the plan for the staffing, what faculty members should be hired when as we go, and which labs should be bought and constructed and when as we go, all this I had to do in the two years.
And I did draw quite a bit on the
One of the purposes of my mission there really was to establish some kind of a sister-ship relationship between the two universities.
We need that.
If we have a contact in Kuwait, like the University of Kuwait, that has a relationship with an exchange of professors, exchange of what have you, I think we all gain this.
When you returned to A&M, a trend in enrollment had started.
There were about 110 seniors in the electrical engineering department in 1979.
By 1982, that figure had more than doubled.
What has been the impact of this?
The increase in enrollment, really, is phenomenal, as we all know.
would not really completely condone measures of restricting enrollment as such.
It has to be...
This is a state institution, as far as I'm concerned.
This is my own opinion.
It's a state institution.
It's a rich state institution.
It's not a poor institution.
And it's supposed to be
training sons and daughters of the state of Texas and what have you, and I just can't see a place like this restricting enrollment by the means that they are doing it.
But it was a fact, and we had to face it, that we have many people walking in and we did not have enough faculty.
This is the
There was some talk about not enough space to schedule our classroom meetings and what have you.
There was some talk like this, and this is why the next building was built.
But I think it is highly important that we try to hire good faculty, and not only hire them, be able to retain
I mean, we should have good working conditions and good working relationships so that we can retain people.
And we can have them work.
So devotion rather than being disappointed, mistreated, what have you.
We have to have good working conditions so that we can retain good faculty.
You're right about it.
Now, what happened when they increased?
If you see our classes now, I teach 338 very often.
And we have all the juniors at any time.
So it's 130 people or 125, this kind of range.
When this happened, the enrollment increase, I did suggest that we put them all in the same room.
And one professor would teach them.
We're doing this with 338, and we're doing it with some of the non-EE major courses, the service courses we give to the others.
We group them in the auditorium down there.
This is a system that is new to the United States.
In the States, traditionally, we've had small classes
and personal contacts between the teacher and the student.
We always had a high ratio.
But in Europe it has been the mode of operation for decades and for maybe some universities for a thousand years.
There is a lecture room and anyone can walk in and can have a thousand people in it.
And you have a professor there
at the very end of it, talking, and everybody's gaining learning knowledge, you see, from there.
So it's a new kind of thing for us, really, but it's a very workable thing.
The only thing with it that people should realize is that the professor in Europe who gives that lecture is not anyone.
You see what I mean?
I mean, if I'm going to have an auditorium with a thousand people in it and someone's going to talk about thermodynamics or electrical circuits, he must be someone who has done it over years.
He knows what he's talking about.
He has written it.
He has rehearsed it.
He has videotaped it.
This caliber of man is what you need for this kind of lecture.
It cannot work with the idea...
with the attitude of what a fool can do and any other fool can't.
Just go in and teach them the darn thing.
So we are in the process of meeting large classes, elections for large classes.
And it has its pros, it has its cons, but it is one way of facing the increased enrollment.
You can do that.
You can do that.
If your professors would get off their butts, you see, I mean it.
And do not hate teaching and do not hide behind research.
They do nothing, you see.
Some of them just pretend to do research and they don't.
Or whatever they do is garbage, which is very common.
This is very, very common, you see.
And many people try to get out of teaching any way they can, you see.
It happens.
Why?
I really believe that we have a lack in the, what would you call that?
A lack of, I hate to say it, devotion.
You see, what happens to me, the way I think about it, the way I've seen it, the way I think about it, is that there are several levels of devotion, okay?
I guess the first one is that of the monks in a monastery.
They have nothing but worship.
They do nothing but worship.
It is my belief, my conviction, that the university professors come next.
Are we really that devoted as professors in this university?
This is very important.
If we are not, why are we not that devoted?
What is distracting me
from my research and my students.
I worry because there is no fairness here or whatever is there.
What is it?
We have to give people a very good working condition so that they can come next to the monastery and devotion.
How has the quality of students changed in the past 16 years?
Somehow, I don't want to be critical of the new generation, but somehow they were, in the past, in all the time, they were better prepared, a little bit.
But it is also very fortunate that our own students now are just as serious as the old ones.
I mean, I do not see any difference between the, I don't want to say discipline, but discipline.
In the classroom here and 16 years ago, I see them very polite, very serious.
They come to class and they listen and they're respectful and the what have you.
But somehow the high school education might have changed a little bit.
I don't know.
Maybe there are too many things, many, many new things, you know, that
that interferes with their drilling and training and this kind of things.
Maybe more sports, more travels, more TV, whatever.
Somehow there's a little bit of a change.
The way I see it, it's not really that major.
And I've always thought that repetition is good.
and a review is good no matter how good you are at it.
I do not at all object or refrain from, in any class, no matter how high a level they did, of just going back to basics for a few minutes.
There's nothing wrong with that.
But somehow I think the kids are different in this way.
They probably are broader in culture and education than before.
But I wouldn't say it's a very measured choice.
And this school, we have been reporting that they are really serious about their studies.
How has electrical engineering curriculum improved over the last 16 years in the department?
We, in 77, when I came back from Kuwait, I did suggest to Dr. Jones at the time, we had trouble, as I could feel,
Well, let me put it this way.
I had a son at the time who was going to electrical engineering here.
So he finished in 1980, AA.
My second son, I have two boys.
My second son finished last year, AA.
So my concern with this department was not only because I worked here.
My own kids were educated here.
So I didn't show concern at the time to Dr. Jones as a parent and as a colleague that things are not going well in the way the kids are being taught here.
And I suggested to him that we establish a curriculum committee that will look closely at all the syllabi of the courses and the courses themselves, are they up to date or not.
Should we be updated?
Should we introduce new courses or not?
Should we change the core course requirements, drop one and add one, or what have you?
So we did establish a varying committee that year, and we still have one now.
I chaired it for two years then.
And yeah, we changed.
We introduced new courses continuously.
And we have changed, and we're changing now to the core requirements.
So the curriculum is being dynamic.
It's being updated all the time.
It's being looked at.
Okay.
How would you rank electrical engineering at A&M with other schools?
Again, what do you rank them by?
Top 20, top 30, top 10?
What do you mean by ranking?
Yeah, how you feel that we compare to the other schools.
You see, we were compared last year, two years ago, nationally, our graduate program, our department, and they put us at 69 out of 99.
But that survey was not fair.
I mean, I know it was biased because we were not handled correctly.
I mean, many, many, not only us.
But many other schools, the data about them was not correct.
It was not complete.
And I would say that we are better than 69 out of 99.
Where do you think that we should go on?
I would say that knowing the school that I have in touch with, my colleagues from other schools in Purdue and Iowa State and Berkeley and what have you,
I would say that we would be in the top 40.
Has the electrical engineering department at A&M had any defense contracts since you've been here?
There's some work for the Air Force that they've been doing all the time.
Do you know what for?
No.
When did students here first start designing integrated circuits?
I would not be able to tell you that either.
I would not tell you.
What other changes of any kind have you seen in the electrical engineering department?
Changes that were very upsetting to me, and I hope that we get over them, are still going on today.
See, if you look at us, we are a department that lost one-third of its faculty last year.
The department head that we had, Mr. Jones, has been terminated.
We have an interim head, and we're looking for a head.
So we're looking for a department head, and we're looking for a third of our faculty.
I think this is a very sad situation, and I hope we get over it very soon.
Otherwise, we're going to be in trouble for years to come.
What do you think was the cause for the loss of faculty?
The treatment, the working conditions, the administration.
There was no leadership.
There was no leadership.
There was arbitrary decisions.
I mean, people cannot be arbitrarily promoted and paid, you see.
I mean, I can't promote you because I like you and I give you 10% raise and I don't give you anything on no basis.
See, people do not feel secure.
And when you're young, you know, you just run.
You run fast when you're in a situation like that.
Okay.
Is there anything else at all that you'd like to say?

i would like to say that this is the alma mater of my two sons my two sons my two boys i have a very deep rooted interest in it okay and until i retire if i'm still here i am going to do my best and i really hope that it does come back revive after what we have been in

we are we are not we're coming from a very sad situation that many of the students are not aware of if you remember last year you see mr page was changed and mr john was changed you know we lost five department heads of state this is what we have today you don't know about it but this one is i think this college deserves a much better administration a much better planning and a much better future
It's a rich college.
It has a lot of devoted kids in it.
The kids are serious kids, polite and serious.
I can see any reason why we cannot really improve our status nationally and keep our reputation and improve it.
Well, thank you for your time.
You bet.
